awd_titl_txt: S&AS: COLLAB: Organization of the 2018 Smart and Autonomous Systems (S&AS) PI Meeting
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this award is to organize the inaugural Principal Investigators (PI) meeting for the Smart and Autonomous Systems (S&AS) program. As this is a new program, the PI meeting will set the intellectual tone for and create a community around this new NSF program, centered at intelligent physical systems that are cognizant, taskable, reflective, ethical, and knowledge-rich. The PI meeting will bring together researchers, companies, and program officers who are actively engaged in S&AS to provide cross-project coordination in terms of common intellectual challenges, methods for education and training, best practices in terms of transition of results, and a lasting repository illustrating the research ideas explored and milestones achieved by the S&AS projects. The PI meeting will take place during April 5-6, 2018, in Washington DC, and the format will include short presentations by all the attending PIs, poster sessions, keynote speeches, and panel discussions. Invitations to the meeting will include all PIs with active S&AS grants, program managers involved with related programs, as well as industry representatives and members of the press.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Outcomes

The Inaugural Smart and Autonomous Systems (S&AS) PI Meeting

April 5?6, 2018, Hilton Old Town Alexandria, Alexandria, Virginia

Magnus Egerstedt and Calin Belta

 

The inaugural Smart and Autonomous Systems (S&AS) PI Meeting was held on April 5?6, 2018 at the Hilton Alexandria Old Town in Alexandria, Virginia. This report summarizes how the PI meeting was structured as well as reports on the results from the post-meeting survey, and comments on what worked well in anticipation of future S&AS PI Meetings.

As the Smart and Autonomous Systems Program is a new NSF program, theinaugural PI meeting was carefully designed to help define and set the intellectual tone for the program. At the same time, the program was crafted in such a way that it would help facilitate the creation of a strong community, focusing on intelligent physical systems that are cognizant, taskable, reflective, ethical, and knowledge-rich.

Given the two over-arching ambitions (intellectual themes and community creation) the PI meeting brought together researchers, companies, and program officers who are actively engaged in S&AS with the ambition to provide cross-project coordination in terms of common intellectual challenges, methods for education and training, and best practices in terms of transition of results.

In order to ensure that the outcomes from the PI meeting resulted in a lastingrepository illustrating the research ideas explored and milestones achieved by the S&AS projects, a dedicated website was set up to this effect, available at http://robotics.gatech.edu/SASPI. Additionally, all PIs in the program participated in Lightning Presentations, and their presentations are available to the public on the website at http://robotics.gatech.edu/SASPI/presentations.

In addition to the presentations by the S&AS PIs, panel sessions and plenaries were part of the program. They were selected in order to highlight particular aspects of the key intellectual themes. The plenaries were selected to call out different intellectual themes within the program, with the first plenary being an ecology talk with relevance to longduration autonomy. The second plenary looked at machine learning and perceptionwhile the third plenary investigated what it takes to go from solutions that work once in the lab to truly robust autonomy solutions:

One important aspect of the PI meeting was to build a strong sense communityaround the S&AS themes. To this end, a PI working dinner as well as a poster session were included in the program to facilitate cooperation and community building.

 The S&AS program provides an opportunity to address deep fundamental questionsin the science of autonomy, which are not addressed in other NSF programs such as the CPS and the NRI programs. There is an opportunity to create a community that addresses challenges in autonomy. The PI meeting reflected this observation both in terms of structure and in terms of content.

 Not surprising, it was found, through the panel discussions, that machine learning plays an increasingly central role for the types of questions addressed in the S&AS program. Explainability, scalability, response time, and integration of learning algorithms are challenges that many projects funded by this program need to address.

Additionally, the creation of a general computational theory of morality and social rules for autonomy is hard but needed. The incorporation of some level of ethical norms in autonomous systems is a challenge and the S&AS program might be the right home for this type of ambitious endeavor. One common theme that emerged throughout the PI meeting was that testing and comparing theoretical and computational frameworks requires the creation of testbeds for autonomy. This is important and not straightforward to achieve within the standard funding mechanisms.

It also was made clear through the PI meeting panels that many of the fundamental questions addressed in this NSF program are of interest to other funding agencies such as ONR, AFOSR, ARPA-E. There is an opportunity to create inter-agency programs focused on the theory of autonomy.
